children.children: The Baltimore City Open Land Data (BOLD) web application is an interactive, parcel-based data information retrieval system.
BOLD enables all users from to search and select property-related data for a single property or multiple properties, based on a variety of attributes.
Where does the data come from?

Data for BOLD has been gathered from multiple sources including the Baltimore Neighborhood Indicators Alliance, Baltimore City Department of Housing, and Open Baltimore (coming soon!). For a full list of data sets, please visit ...[codebook]
BOLD was developed by BNIA with design continual input and feedback from the Community Law Center and members of the Tax Sale Workgroup. Funding for this project was provided by the Abell Foundation.

The Baltimore City Open Land Data (BOLD) project advances the use of data-driven tools for developing solutions to vacant property problems and educating partners to more effectively prevent and redress property abandonment in order to revitalize distressed neighborhoods. To achieve these goals, BNIA-JFI and the Community Law Center collaborated with community, non-profit, and local government partners, to create this exciting new mapping and data tool. BOLD integrates multiple property-related datasets at the parcel-level to allows its users to better understand, analyze, and reform property-related policies, like tax sale foreclosure, that might have negative impacts on vulnerable populations, communities, and the city.
For more information on this project, visit https://bniajfi.org/currentprojects/baltimore-open-land-data/
For more information about the BOLD website or the data available through this website, please contact:

The Baltimore Neighborhood Indicators Alliance, Jacob France Institute
bnia-jfi@ubalt.edu
410-837-4377

Community Law Center provides legal assistance to nonprofit and neighborhood organizations in Baltimore City and across Maryland. If your organization would like legal assistance to operate your organization, address nuisance issues in your community, respond to zoning or liquor license concerns, create  green space or urban agriculture use, or embark on other activities that involve legal issues, please contact CLC or visit their website.

dictionaries.layerdescription: The Single Property Look Up feature allows users to view all available information about a single property. Once an address is entered, the most currently available data will be displayed on the right side of the screen, with options for displaying multiple years' worth of data for that property in a report. For more guidance see the Help guide.

The Multiple Property Look Up feature allows users to search multiple properties meeting any of the desired criteria searchable in the search boxes below. For example, users can search multiple properties by owner name or address, or search for properties sold in a particular year. For more guidance see the Help guide. All data for this feature comes from MD Property View, see the data dictonary for more details on this dataset.

fields.name: grnt_name
fields.description: Name of the person who last sold the house (or previous owners name)

fields.name: tradate
fields.description: Date the house was last sold

fields.name: considr
fields.description: Amount of money paid for the property when last sold-may be zero

fields.name: nfmttlvl
fields.description: Land value plus improvement value- may be zero

dictionaries.layerdescription: Residential properties issued citations from the Baltimore City Department of Housing. DHCD's Code Enforcement Division enforces the city's housing, zoning, building and related codes. Years available: 2010 - 2017. Most recent year available: 2017.

fields.name: description
fields.description: Short description of the violation (may be blank)

dictionaries.layerdescription: Properties that have a "Foreclosure Rights of Redemption" (tax foreclosure) or "Foreclosure" (mortgage foreclosure) filed against the owners in the Baltimore City Circuit Court.  Properties listed in this dataset are recorded when a case is filed. Not all cases result in a foreclosure. For more information on the results of a specific case go to http://casesearch.courts.state.md.us/casesearch/ and search by "Case Number". Years available: 2010 - 2017. Most recent year available: 2017.

Residential properties receiving housing code violations from the Baltimore City Department of Housing. Properties may have multiple violations in a single year and may have multiple violations over time. DHCD's Code Enforcement Division enforces the city's housing, zoning, building and related codes. Years available: 1998-2009 (limited data, may not be complete), 2010-2016. Most recent year available: 2016.

Historic tax credits are financial incentives for residential or commercial rehabilitation projects that require property-owners to follow certain preservation standards. The Baltimore City Commission on Historic and Architectural Preservation administers a 10-year comprehensive property tax credit granted on the increased assessment directly resulting from qualifying improvements to historic properties. The duration of the credit is for 10 years, and is applicable to properties located in designated areas of significant historical value. Both homeowners and commercial properties are eligible for this tax credit. Properties listed in this dataset are those with the Historic Tax Credit applied to them. Years available: 2012 - 2016. Most recent year available: 2016. 2017 data coming soon!

fields.name: historic_txcr
fields.description: If a property is in this dataset there has been a historic tax credit filed for this property

dictionaries.layerdescription: To help homeowners deal with large assessment increases on their principal residence, state law has established the Homestead Property Tax Credit. The Homestead Credit limits the increase in taxable assessments each year to a fixed percentage. Every county and municipality in Maryland is required to limit taxable assessment increases to 10% or less each year. The cap for Baltimore City is 4%. Properties in this data set are those with the homestead tax credit applied to them. Years available: 2013 - 2016. Most recent year available: 2016. 2017 data coming soon!

fields.name: homestead_txcr
fields.description: If a property is in this dataset there has been a homestead tax credit filed for this property

dictionaries.layerdescription: Business establishments that possess a Class A (Off Sale package goods no on-premises consumption - 6 days, 6:00 a.m.- Midnight. No Sunday sales except Sundays between Thanksgiving Day and New Year's Day upon issuance of a special license for each Sunday) or BD7 (tavern) business license that allows them to sell beer, wine, or liquor. Other liquor licenses to restaurants or on premise consumption were not included in this data set. Years available 2010 - 2014. Most recent year available: 2014. Updated data coming soon!
Locations of Community Managed Open Spaces in Baltimore

dictionaries.layerdescription: There are three different types of permits within this dataset. DEM permits are issued for structural demolitions. This may be a demolition of the entire property or a room/space within the property. The cost of the demolition can be a clue to which type of demolition permit it is. USE permits are issued to use the property in a particular manner (for example, use premises as a single-family dwelling, or use premises as a grocery store. COM permits are issued for work on a property that may include installing something onto or into the property, or non-structural demolition and repairs. Years available: 2010 -2018. Most recent year available: up to 5/6/2018.

fields.name: prop_use
fields.description: Proposed use of building (may be blank)

dictionaries.layerdescription: Properties with receivership action filed in court. Year available: 2010-2014. Most recent year available: 2014.

fields.name: v2v
fields.description: Is the property a vacants to value property (y/n)?

dictionaries.layerdescription: Residential properties with city liens sold as tax certificates at the annual tax lien certificate sale held in May. Tax sales are used to collect delinquent real property taxes and other unpaid charges to the city, which are liens against the real property. The tax certificate sale is a public online auction of City lien interests on properties that occurs annually in May. Years available 2010 - 2017. Most recent year available: 2017. 2018 data coming soon!

fields.name: taxsale_year
fields.description: Year property was listed in tax sale auction

fields.name: homestead
fields.description: Does property currently have homestead tax credit applied?

fields.name: winning_bidder_name
fields.description: Name of the winner bidder at tax auction

fields.name: winning_bidder_business_name
fields.description: Business name of the winner bidder at tax auction

fields.name: winning_bidder_addr
fields.description: Address of the winner bidder at tax auction

fields.name: llc_resident_agent
fields.description: The resident agent listed for the LLC if property bid on by an LLC (this data should be confirmed by user for accuracy)

fields.name: winning_bidder_zip
fields.description: Zip Code of the winner bidder at tax auction

fields.name: num_bids
fields.description: Number of bids property received at tax auction

dictionaries.layerdescription: Vacant properties and lots available through the Vacants to Value program (V2V). This program is Baltimore City's initiative to get more of Baltimore's vacant and abandoned properties cleaned up and redeveloped more quickly, efficiently, and economically. V2V is streamlining government processes, targeting resources, and leveraging private investment to maximize the repair and rehabilitation of blighted property. Year's available: 2008 -2011. Most recent year available: 2011. Year is based on when the property's occupancy type was recorded in system. Some properties have no year associated with them. For more information see:http://www.vacantstovalue.org/Explore.aspx#

Properties classified as being vacant and abandoned that have been cited and are owned by Baltimore City. Baltimore City has come to own these properties through a variety of ways including (but not limited to) eminent domain, unpaid tax or water bills, and purchase. This dataset does not represent the full scale of all vacant and abandoned properties in the city. Years available: 1994 -2009 limited data (not all data may be available); 2010 -2017. Most recent year available: 2017.
Community Statistical Areas for Baltimore City.
This dataset is the 2011 Maryland zip codes based on 2011 Md PropertyView data.
